title: 113_hr4173
content: The Act is titled the "Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing Act of 2014". It establishes the Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing Program. The Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing program guarantees loans for brownfield redevelopment and urban renewal projects. Eligibility requires submission of an application to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. To be eligible for a loan guarantee under the Program, a government, agency, or BRAC redevelopment project must submit a master plan meeting specific requirements, a certification of environmental remediation need, and any additional information requested by the Secretary. Loans guaranteed under the Program must be used for redevelopment costs. A loan guaranteed under the Program must be used for costs related to redeveloping brownfields and promoting urban renewal, including acquisition, remediation, relocation of facilities, and site preparation. Additional information may be required by the Secretary for loan eligibility. The Program guarantees loans for redeveloping brownfields and promoting urban renewal, covering costs like acquisition, remediation, and site preparation. A local government or agency cannot receive a loan guarantee if responsible for contaminating the brownfield to be redeveloped. Additionally, only one outstanding loan is allowed at a time, with a minimum principal amount of $25,000,000. The Program guarantees loans for redevelopment projects with a minimum principal amount of $25,000,000 and a maximum of $150,000,000. The loan's interest rate and duration are negotiated between the lender and borrower, with a term to maturity between 20 to 30 years. Repayment terms are also specified. The loan guarantee program establishes loans with a term to maturity of 20-30 years. Repayment of principal or interest is not required within 10 years, with repayment starting no later than 15 years after the loan is made. A master plan must describe the brownfield redevelopment project funded by the loan. A master plan for a brownfield redevelopment project funded by a loan guarantee must include a project description, schedule, budget, and demonstrate major redevelopment impact on the community through economic development, environmental quality, and restoration. Key information includes non-Federal funds commitment, long-term job creation, and environmental remediation of brownfield sites. The master plan for a brownfield redevelopment project funded by a loan guarantee must include details such as the number of long-term jobs created, environmental remediation of brownfield sites, economic and environmental impact on the community, amount of affordable housing, reduction of vehicle congestion and emissions, integration of green technology, improvement in air quality, and incorporation of complete streets planning and transit-oriented development. The criteria for selecting local governments, redevelopment agencies, and BRAC projects for loan guarantees under the Program include evidence of non-Federal investment commitments, an approved remediation action plan, and consideration of factors like improvement in air quality and incorporation of complete streets planning and transit-oriented development. The Program criteria for selecting local governments, redevelopment agencies, and BRAC projects for loan guarantees consider existing Federal assistance and grants. The full faith and credit of the United States is pledged for all guarantees made under this section. The Federal Government guarantees loans for eligible obligations, protecting against liability for environmental remediation. The Secretary processes requests using a similar approval process as for housing loan guarantees. The Federal Government guarantees loans for eligible obligations, using an approval process similar to housing loan guarantees. Loan applicants must demonstrate a viable repayment schedule and provide sufficient collateral, which may include grants under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. The Secretary may not require grants as collateral for loan guarantees under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. Congressional oversight is required before final approval of any loan guarantee. Definitions for a BRAC redevelopment project are provided. Definitions for a BRAC redevelopment project include the terms "BRAC redevelopment project," "brownfield," and "local redevelopment agency." The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to brownfield redevelopment projects, including "local redevelopment agency," "remediation action plan," "Program," and "Secretary." The Program, established under this section, is defined as the Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing program. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development is defined as the Secretary. The Secretary is required to issue regulations within 6 months of enactment to carry out the Program. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2015 for costs of guaranteed loans under this section, available through fiscal year 2019.
